A truck travels north at a constant speed on a straight North-South road covering a distance of 35\ \text{km} in 30\ \text{min}. Find the displacement, average speed and average velocity for the entire trip. Express your speed and velocity in km/h.

Two Cars Moving Towards Each Other on a Straightline
Two cars travel on a straight East-West road. Initially the cars are 150\, \text{km} apart. Both cars travel at a constant speed of 60\, \text{km/h} with respect to the ground; Car A heads to the east and B to the west. (a) Write the average velocity of the two cars using x-axis in the East-Wast direction, taking the direction to the East direction as positive. (b) Find the displacements of the two cars when each has traveled 50 km. (c) Find the time it takes each car to travel 50 km. (d) Find the time when they are 50 km apart if the time is zero when they were 150 km apart.
(a) v_{A} = +60\, \text{km/h}, v_{B} = -60\, \text{km/h}. (b) v_{A} = +50\, \text{km/h}, v_{B} = -50\, \text{km/h}. (c) 50\,\text{s}. (d) 75\,\text{s}.
a
From the description, A is going East (+x-direction). Therefore,
v_{Ax} = +60\, \text{km/h}.
But, since B is moving West (-x-direction),
v_{Bx} = -60\, \text{km/h}.
You can drop subscript x in these symbols as long as you have clearly stated positive and negative directions.
b
ASince the difference x_f - x_i will be positive for A but negative for B, their displacements will be
\amp \Delta x_A = + 50\,\text{km} \amp \Delta x_B = - 50\,\text{km}
c
For time, only the average speed matters. Here it is v=60\, \text{km/h} for both. Hence, time will be same for both given by
\Delta t = \frac{50\,\text{km}}{60\, \text{km/h}} = \frac{50\,\text{km}}{1\, \text{km/s}} = 50\,\text{s}.
c
For them to be 50\,\text{km} apart at the end, each must have moved 75\,\text{km} since they were 150\,\text{km} apart initially and they are moving towards each other. Hence, time will be
t = \frac{75\,\text{km}}{60\, \text{km/h}} = 75\, \text{s}.
Two Runners Running Towards Each Other With Different Speeds
Two runners A and B start out at two ends of a 100\text{-m} straight track, and run at constant speeds. Runner A has a speed of 30\ \text{km/h} and runner B has a speed of 20\ \text{km/h}. Where and when they would meet?
60\,\text{ m} from A at 7.2\,\text{s}.
Let us place A at origin and B at x=100\,\text{m} = 0.100\,\text{km} at t=0. Let they meet at x=d (km) at t=T (h). Clearly,
\amp d = 30 T, \amp 0.100- d = 20 T.
We need to solve for d and T. Adding them we get
T = \frac{0.100}{50} = 2\times 10^{-3}\,\text{h}.
Then,
d = 30 \times 2 \times 10^{-3} = 0.060\,\text{ km} = 60\,\text{ m}.
That is, they will meet 60\,\text{ m} from A. Let's also write T in seconds.
T = 2\times 10^{-3} \times 3600 = 7.2\,\text{s}.

Two Runners in a Race - Relative Motion
Karl and Justin are in a 10\text{-km} race. Karl runs at a constant speed of 12\text{ km/h} and Justin at 11.5\text{ km/h}. You can assume t = 0 at the start and their speeds are their full values at the start.
(a) Who will finish the race first?
(b) What is the value of time, t , when Karl finishes?
(c) What is the value of time, t , when Justin finishes?
(d) If Karl finishes first, how far away from the finish is Justin when Karl crosses the finish line, and if Justin finishes first, same question for Karl.
(e) How far apart are the two runners after 12\text{ min} ?
(a) Think who is faster? (b) Use v = d/t. (c) Same as (b). (d) Use d = v t on slower with t the finish time of the faster. (e) Multiply the difference in their speeds by time.
(a) Karl, (b) 50\text{ min}, (c) 52.2\text{ min}, (d) 0.417\text{ km}, (e) 100\text{ m}.
(a)
(a) Since Karl's speed is greater, he will finish first.
(b)
(b) Using v = d/t on Karl gives
t = \dfrac{d}{v} = \dfrac{10}{12}\text{ hr} = 50\text{ min}.
(c)
(c) Using v = d/t on Justin gives
t = \dfrac{d}{v} = \dfrac{10}{11.5}\text{ hr} = 52.2\text{ min}.
(d)
(d) Since Karl finishes at t= 50\text{ min} , Justin will have covered the following distance by then (note: I need to convert 50\text{ min} = 5/6\text{ hr} since the speed is given in per \text{hr} unit.)
d = vt = 11.5\times \dfrac{5}{6} = 9.583\text{ km}.
That means, the remaining distance is
10 - 9.583 = 0.417\text{ km}.
(e)
(e) Using d = v t with v being the difference of the two speeds. Also, since the speeds have time in \text{hr}, we need to convert t to \text{hr} as well.
d = (12-11.5)\times \dfrac{12}{60} = 0.1\text{ km} = 100\text{ m}.
You can also do this part by first finding how far Karl and Justin went, and then subtracting their distances.

Two Stones Thrown Vertically at Different Times Reaching Ground at the Same Time
Two stones are dropped from the roof of a 50\text{-m} tall building. The first stone is released smoothly from rest, and after 0.5\text{ sec} later, the second stone is thrown vertically down with an intial speed such that they reach the ground at the same time.
(a) With what initial speed was the second stone thrown?
(b) With what speed did the first stone hit the ground?
(c) With what speed did the second stone hit the ground?
Both stones follown free fall motion related in time by t_1 = t_2 + 0.5 . Set up two sets of equations, one for each stone and solve them simultaneously.
(a) 5.29\text{ m/s} , (b) 31.4\text{ m/s}, (c) 31.78\text{ m/s} . (a),(b),(c)
(a), (b) , (c), all three parts can be solved by setting up two sets of equations, one set for each stone, and relation t_1 = t_2 + 0.5 for the times of the two stones. Let us use positive y axis up to keep track of signs with origin at the place the motions started. That will make y_i = 0 and y_f = -50 \text{ m}. Let us use subscript 1 for stone 1 and 2 for stone 2, and drop y from subscripts.
For stone 1, we have the following two equations.
-50 \amp = 0 - \dfrac{1}{2}\, 9.81\, t_1^2, v_{1f} \amp= 0 - 9.81\, t_1,
For stone 2, we have the following two equations.
-50 \amp= v_{2i}\, t_2 - \dfrac{1}{2}\, 9.81\, t_2^2, v_{2f} \amp = v_{2i} - 9.81\, t_2,
with
t_2 = t_1 - 0.5.
From Eq. , we solve for t_1 and keep the positive root as our answer.
t_1 = 3.2\text{ sec}.
Therefore, t_2 = 2.7\text{ sec}.
Using t_1 in Eq. give,
v_{1f} = - 9.81 \times 3.2 = -31.4\text{ m/s}.
Using t_2 in Eq. gives
v_{2i} = \dfrac{-50 + 4.9 \times 2.7^2 } { 2.7 } = -5.29\text{ m/s}.
Using t_2 and v_{2i} in Eq. gives
v_{2f} = -5.29 - 9.81 \times 2.7 = -31.78\text{ m/s}.
Tennis Balls Launched Vertically at Different Times
Two balls are launched straight up at different times from a tennis ball launching machine. The second ball is launched at the time the first ball is at the top of its flight. If the launching speed of the balls are 20\text{ m/s}, (a) where would the two balls hit each other and (b) what will be the time when they hit the ball if t=0 at the instant of the launch of the second ball? Assume the effect of the air resistance to be negligible on the motion.
First find the height the first ball will fly before falling back.
(a) 15.3\text{ m}, (b) 1.02\text{ s}. (a),(b)
Let y=0 at the launch point with positive y axis pointed up. The first ball reaches y=h before falling with
y = h = \dfrac{-v_i^2}{2g} = \dfrac{-20^2}{2\times 9.81} = 20.39\text{ m}.
Now, ball 1 moves in the negative y direction at t=0 starting at y_{1i}=20.39\text{ m} with v_{1i}=0 and ball 2 moves in the positive y direction y_{2i}=0 starting with v_{2i}=20\text{ m/s}. We want y where they hit each other, i.e., y_{1f} = y_{2f} = y. Let t be the duration since ball 2 was launched. For the two equations we get
\text{ ball 1: } y - 20.39 = - \dfrac{1}{2}\times 9.81\, t^2 \text{ ball 2: } y = 20\, t - \dfrac{1}{2}\times 9.81\, t^2
Subtracting first equation from the second we get
20.39 = 20\, t\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ t = 1.02\text{ s}.
Using this t we get
y = 20.39 - \dfrac{1}{2}\times 9.81\times 1.02^2 = 15.3\text{ m}.
Motion with Two Constant Acceleration Segments
A hockey puck is shot at 40\text{ m/s}. Initially, the puck decelerates at 3\text{ m/s}^2, but after 50\text{ m}, the puck runs into a rough patch, where the puck has constant deceleration 12\text{ m/s}^2 and comes to rest.
(a) How far from the initial place does the puck come to rest?
(b) How much time did it take for the puck to come to rest?
You will need to set up two sets of equations with final velocity of segment 1 is equal to the initial velocity of segment 2.
(a) 104.3\text{ m}, (b) 4.31\text{ sec} (a),(b)
(a) and (b):
There are two constant-acceleration segments in this problem, such that final velocity and final position of the first segment is the initial velocity and initial position of the second segment. Let us denote the quantities of the first and second segments by subscripts 1 and 2, respectively.
We point positive x axis from the initial point of the first segment towards the final point where the puck comes to rest. Using this coordinate system, we have the following knowns and unknowns for segment 1.
First Segment:
Suppressing units in calculations, we list knowns and unknowns.
\amp a_1 = - 3,\ \ t_1 = ?, \amp x_{1,i} = 0,\ \ v_{1,i} = 40,\ \ x_{1,f} = 50,\ \ v_{1,f} = ?,
The equation v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2 a x gives
v_{1,f}^2 = 40^2 + 2 \times (-3) \times 50 = 1600 - 300 = 1300.
This gives
v_{1,f} = \pm 36.1\text{ m/s}.
Since the puck is moving in the same direction as the direction of the positive x axis, the positive root is the right choice here.
v_{1,f} = + 36.1\text{ m/s}.
Now, using v_f = v_i + a t, we get
t = \dfrac{v_f - v_i}{a} = \dfrac{36.1 - 40}{-3} = 1.3\text{ sec}.
Second Segment:
Let us use t_2 for t_{2,f} - t_{2,i} and place another origin at x_{2,i}.
\amp a_2 = - 12,\ \ t_2 = ?, \amp x_{2,i} = 0,\ \ v_{2,i} = 36.1,\ \ x_{2,f} = ?,\ \ v_{2,f} = 0,
Using v_f = v_i + a t, we get t
t_2 = \dfrac{v_{2,f} - v_{2,i}}{a_2} = \dfrac{0 - 36.1}{-12} = 3.01\text{ sec}.
Using x = v_i t +\dfrac{1}{2}at^2, we get
x_{2,f} = 36.1\times 3.01 +\dfrac{1}{2}\times(-12) \times 3.01^2 = 54.3\text{ m}.
(a) The total distance is 50 + 54.3 = 104.3\text{ m}.
(b) The total time is
t_1 + t_2 = 1.3 + 3.01 = 4.31\text{ sec}.
(Calculus) Varying Acceleration During Parachute Jump
A parachuter drops off an air plane with zero vertical speed. Suppose magnitude of acceleration of the parachuter varies linearly in time, from g at t=0 to zero at t=\tau .
(a) What is the speed at an arbitrary instant t before the acceleration is zero?
(b) What is the speed at the instant \tau ?
(c) How far has he fallen in time \tau ?
(a) Integrate a_y. (b) Evaluate at t = \tau . (c) Integrate v_y.
(a) \dfrac{g}{2\tau}\, t^2 - g t , (b) \dfrac{1}{2} g\tau, (c) \dfrac{1}{3}\,g \tau^2. (a)
(a) We would find velocity by integrating the acceleration, and then get the speed from the absolute value. The magnitude of acceleration drops from g to zero in time \tau. Therefore, we have the following formula for the magnitude of the acceleration at instant t.
a(t) = \begin{cases} \dfrac{g}{\tau}\, |\tau - t| \amp t \le \tau\\ 0 \amp t \gt \tau \end{cases}
Let positive y axis be pointed up so that
a_y(t) = \begin{cases} \frac{g}{\tau} t - g \amp t \le \tau\\ 0 \amp t \gt \tau \end{cases}
Now, we integrate this from t = 0 to t=t. With v_y=0 at t = 0.
v_y(t) - 0 = \int_0^{t} a_y(t)\, dt = -\dfrac{g}{2\tau}\, t^2 - g t.
Therefore, speed at arbitrary instant is
v = |\dfrac{g}{2\tau}\, t^2 - g t|.
(b)
(b) Speed at instant \tau will be obtained by setting t= \tau in the answer for part (a) and taking the absolute value.

(Calculus) Varying Acceleration and Terminal Speed
Consider an object falling vertically. In a coordinate system with the positive y axis pointed down, the acceleration a_y has the following expression. Let y=0 at t=0.
a_y = g - \gamma v_y,
where g is acceleration due to gravity, and \gamma is a constant, called the damping constant.
(a) Show that at the instant the acceleration is zero, the speed is
v = \dfrac{g}{\gamma}.
The speed is called the terminal speed. We will denote it by v_T .
(b) Prove that velocity at arbitrary instant t is given by
v_y = v_T\left( 1 - e^{-\gamma\, t} \right).
(c) Prove that the y coordinate at arbitrary instant t is given by
y = v_T\, t - \dfrac{v_T}{\gamma}\left( 1 - e^{-\gamma\, t} \right).
(a) Set a_y=0. (b) Write a_y = dv_y/dt, then change variable to k = -\gamma v_y + g and integrate. (c) Integrate v_y.
Already given in problem statement. (a)
(a) Setting a_y=0 and v_y = v_T , we imediately get the answer.
v_T = \dfrac{g}{\gamma}.
(b)
(b) We express a_y = dv_y/dt and rearrange to obtain
\dfrac{dv_y}{g - \gamma v_y} = dt.
Integrating this from t=0 to t =t with v_y(0)=0 and v_y(t)=v_y, we get
\ln\left( \dfrac{| g - \gamma v_y|}{g} \right) = -\gamma t.
Since g is larger than \gamma v_y , exponentiating and then rearranging gives.
v_y = \dfrac{g}{\gamma} \left( 1 - e^{-\gamma t}\right),
which is
v_y = v_T\left( 1 - e^{-\gamma\, t} \right).
(c)
(c) Integrating v_y gives the desired answer.
\int dy = \int v_y dt.
Use v_y from (b) and carry out the integration.
y = v_T\, t - \dfrac{v_T}{\gamma}\left( 1 - e^{-\gamma\, t} \right).
